name: Ethanol, denatured, at refueling station, 2022
description:
The ethanol was denatured at the conversion facility, so is 95.25v% ethanol and 4.75v% gasoline (3.95w% denaturant). Data for this process is mainly drawn from Reynolds, 2006 (aka DAI, 2006). It is assumed that the DAI report covers the transport the ethanol to the blending terminal (the "destination" of the report); distance for the subsequent transport to refueling station is included in this process as the author's own estimate. In the modeling of ethanol distribution, the transport of E10 and E85 to the refueling station is counted separately for each component (denatured ethanol and petrol/gasoline). Transport of the ethanol is included in this step; transport of gasoline is accounted by using the ecoinvent "petrol, at regional storage" process which includes transport to refueling station as well as the operation of the refueling station. The process of blending (and its energy use) is included in separate processes, as well as the infrastructure for additional terminals and blending apparatus, "E10, at blending terminal" and "E85, at blending terminal". Infrastructure for refueling stations are included in the processes "E10, pumped into vehicle" and "E85, pumped into vehicle."  [Infrastructure for additional transportation equipment required to distribute EISA volumes of ethanol is NOT included in this process since we are using the ecoinvent "transport" process which includes infrastructure.] 
The production of ethanol utilized in this process assigns inputs to co-products (e.g., wheat kernals and straw, corn grain and stover) based on activities and inputs that are required for the growth and harvest and preprocessing of, e.g., wheat straw, and none that of the activities or inputs that would normally be used to produce, harvest and preprocess, e.g., wheat kernals (so-called "incremental allocation").

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

exchanges.description: transports the ethanol portion of blended E10 and E85 to refueling station from blending terminal. Since the ecoinvent process used for gasoline that's blended with ethanol includes this transport step as well as operations of refueling stations, I'm including this post-blending transport step here as opposed to in the subsequent blending process step. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

secondary shipment of 1 kg of ethanol from conversion plant to intermediate terminal. based on Reynolds (2006) and Morrow et al., 2006. Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

secondary shipment of 1 kg of ethanol from intermediate terminal to "destination" (blending terminal). Reynolds (2006). Using most stringent EURO emission standard though emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

secondary shipment of 1 kg of ethanol from intermediate terminal to "destination" (blending terminal). based on Reynolds (2006). Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. Reynolds specified for this leg an ocean-going vessel, which he says is most likely to be ocean barge. SimaPro library does not differentiate between inland waterway and ocean barge. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

flow.name: Transport, ocean freighter, diesel powered
categoryPath: 4831: Deep Sea, Coastal, and Great Lakes Water Transportation

flow.name: Ethanol, denatured, mixed feedstocks, at conversion facility

exchanges.description: secondary shipment of 1 kg of ethanol from conversion plant to intermediate terminal. based on Reynolds (2006). Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

primary shipments of 1 kg of ethanol directly from conversion plant to "destination" (assumed to mean blending terminal). based on Reynolds (2006) and Morrow et al., 2006. Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

primary shipments of 1 kg of ethanol directly from conversion plant to "destination" (assumed to mean blending terminal). Reynolds (2006). Using most stringent EURO emission standard though emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower.Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

primary shipments of 1 kg of ethanol directly from conversion plant to "destination" (assumed to mean blending terminal). Reynolds (2006). Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

tertiary shipment of 1 kg of ethanol from intermediate terminal to intermediate terminal. Reynolds (2006). Emission mandates in 2022 will undoubtedly be lower so this will be an overestimate of impacts. This is an ocean-going vessel, which Reynolds says is most likely to be ocean barge. No ocean barge in SimaPro library. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)
